Cavendish experiment; It was set in a room in or adjoining his house - the device was not his design it was passed to him and he carried out a few modifications. There was no temperature control in the room (This is most critical) His calculations have been found to be incorrect (Proven by Hutton). @crunchypotato5015   It would work out the same BUT you’d need to remember how you oriented the vectors. In this case he’s using the standard convention (to the right is positive, to the left is negative, and the moon is positioned at zero, for simplicity).  So the vector F_E is positive (points right) and the vector F_S is negative (points to the left) but you could easily reverse them since the convention choice is arbitrary—so long as you keep track of which way is a positive vector and which way is negative, the math works out the same. (In that case, you’d have the same value but with the opposite sign, BUT that would also mean that we switched the convention such that left is positive and right is negative, so when taking both those facts into consideration, you end up with the same vector—has the same magnitude and orientation.  F_net in that case would be positive but since we defined left to be positive, F_net still points to the left as it does when we use the “standard” convention)
